results.content:
I've just finished the first parte of the course - the tutorial. Extremely helpful. Although I suspect you could have learned most of what was taught by reading Gatsby's website, the way that the information was structured and presented in the course makes it a much more effective way to learn the platform. One of the huge benefits is seeing how a JAMStack application, regardless of how simple it is, is built taking advantage of online services.

Just concluded the whole course. John has a great strategy to focus on what he is teaching. Instead of building something from scratch, he provides us with a starter project that has all the structure and styling necessary to build a product relatable to a real-world project while maintaining our attention strictly on what he is explaining. That doesn't mean he refrains from explaining how everything works, he just saves us the time and work of typing it all.

Really enjoyed the course, could not recommend it enough.

results.content:
The course is extremely repetitive. Every section/project starts again from ground-zero explaining what Gatsby is, how to set it up, etc. The course says upfront that you should know react and javascript, yet spends an exuberant amount of time explaining react and javascript concepts.

The Gatsby Tutorial section was good and gave a nice overview of what Gatsby is, and how to use it, but once I move onto the projects, I was left wanting to tear my eyes out from repetitive content.

Additionally, the instructor continuously does not follow best practices (such as, by making all react components classes instead of separating between "stateful" and "stateless", hard-coding pixel values in css, etc.). I understand that some of these things may have been done to "simplify" the content of the course, and that would be fine during the tutorials / demos, but the course projects should be built as a professional would using up-to-date best practices. After all, we are paying for you, the supposed expert on the topic, to show us how to do things right.

Overall, I do not recommend this course. It does contain a decent overview of Gatsby, but you could gain as much by spending a couple hours reading the Gatsby docs. I found the projects to be largely a waste of time as they did not contain much, if any, useful information or insight.

response.content:
Hello Jonathan , thank you for your review! Now let me clarify few things.
I'm sorry but the argument - "but you could gain as much by spending a couple hours reading the Gatsby docs" - is getting really old. It’s always easier to watch someone else do it for you, let them explain difficult things first and only then proclaim - “I could have done it myself”. As far repetition, you  left out some important information. In the beginning of the course students are given two options - Gatsby Tutorial Only or Gatsby Tutorial implemented in the project. I specifically mention that if you watch them both, one after another there is going to be some repetition. If you decided to ignore my advice, how is that my fault? "The course says upfront that you should know react and javascript, yet spends an exuberant amount of time explaining react and javascript concepts." - regardless of the course requirements, more than half of my students are just starting out with react and even javascript. I rather cater to their needs, and cover react,javascript concepts in greater detail even if it upsets some react experts.  Now, the projects part -  "but the course projects should be built as a professional would using up-to-date best practices". First of all,some of the students have actually used projects for freelancing and actually made money off them - so I guess, not everyone finds them useless . Second, each project covers something specific, for example blog project shows how to implement gatsby-mdx,coffee project shows how to implement bootstrap and snipcart etc - if you don't find it useful, again I'm not sure how is that my fault.Lastly, your examples of best practice violations are silly to say the least .If your best argument is - " Too many class based components and occasional px values" - maybe projects are not as bad as you portray them to be. I also never claimed to be an expert. I will always be a student that enjoys sharing what I have learned. Regards, John

results.content: John covers all the bases. You want to code along? He has it. You want to do a project? Follow along and be meticulously guided by his tutorials. He has the resources if you're stumped. I like that he starts with the Gatsby tutorials and then launches into teaching actual projects that help people code along with an end goal in mind. He pairs Gatsby with various backend options. He actually has something that amounts to a finished project or production ready work. Best of all, he responds and I know how hard it must be for him to answer to questions that should be obvious. But he does it anyway. I just wishes that the e-commerce project I did would work but that's on me. He's good. Hope he does more Gatsby tutorials.

I totally loved his teaching style.

results.content:
Very good and detailed tutorials. Very deep introduction to Gatsby.

Missed topics:
- i18n (localization)
- use of existing react components/libs (quick tutorial how to select library and how to do basic integrations of them into gatsby pages)
- how to convert JS scripts of different SDKs into gatsby code (for example: Facebook IM integration on website)

Big THANKS for a great education lectures. Well DONE! I would like to highly recommend this course to others.

results.content:
Definitely one of the best courses, if not the best course for gatsby out there right now. Not only delivers in-depth skills on gatsby but also takes alot of  time to tackle solution from the broader ecosystem like graphql and contentful.

For anyone starting out with gatsby, powering through this huge course will give a great head-start on developing better web-sites in the future and provides an extensive reference to go back to when working on personal projects.

The course material is REALLY up-to-date technology-wise and in it´s implementation details, e.g. relying on latest react-paradigms across the whole project like functional-components and custom-hooks from other libraries.

Also A+ hands-on support provided by the instructor John. I was completely stuck with my own private project using a solution from the course. John could quickly help me out in the comments and I had my thing up and running again in no time.

Would definitely buy again.

results.content:
Normally I don't rate courses before I finish them but this time I really need to make an exception.   

John is a really good instructor (yes he has a bit of an accent but I like it) He has a great teaching style and his introduction to the stack we are going to use is great. In that first section I learned more about Gatsby then in my previous course. 

He is also going to add yet another project where (spoilers) we are going to build a shopping cart from scratch.. so how cool is that!

The only thing I can say is that if you want to learn Gatsby for building beautiful websites.. take this course!

results.content:
Excellent class that surpassed my expectations!
Well explained, not only taught Gatsby but also the ecosystems around it, like most commonly used plugins, CMSes etc. Taught via several beautiful projects and includes all the step-by-step code. 
Only thing I'd have to criticize is that it's a bit stretched - after explaining all of the concepts, they're explained again in the first project in all length. That wouldn't have been necessary. Also, some of the later projects don't really teach any new concepts, it's just a repeat of earlier workflows. Good practice though.

results.content: New Gatsby MDX Blog Project is awesome. I think it is ideal for people already using Gatsby who want to learn about using MDX. I found the wrapRootElement with MDX section especially interesting. Also, the instructor hooks you up with lots of goodies (CSS, MDX examples) so when you're done with the course you can easily use this project as a starter. At the end, you have the basic setup for a tech/coding blog.  I especially like how it uses a main CSS file and Styled Components rather than a generic framework.

results.content:
Very talented guy. I also have a bootstrap course of his. Full of valuable information. If you're reading this, you probably already know what Gatsby is, and I'd highly recommend you this course.

He starts off by covering the basics (what's GraphQL? what's the idea behind static site generators), but the bulk of the course are large projects where you get to see everything in action. His example sites are very big, and cover a lot of ground, so you can be quite certain the topic you are looking for will be covered somewhere in the course.

Assuming you're already familiar with React, HTML, and CSS, this course should really be all you need to go from complete beginner to being able to write production grade Gatsby applications. Provided of course you either code along, or have your own projects you're working on to put your skills into practice.

One thing I wish the instructor had done differently, was to create more structure in the course. It's almost 40 hours of material, but it's split up into only a few sections. I'd rather see the course split up into smaller sections, i.e. Gatsby-Image, Setting up pages programatically, Contentful, Pagination, SEO, etc, rather than having all those topics covered in one section that contains over a hundred videos. It would make things easier to navigate through, and it would make it easier to see what you're going to learn in a project. That's not going to detract from my 5 star rating, because there's too much good material here.
